characters: THE END CREDITS ROLL AS WE SEE--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dense, lush rain forests of the eastern slopes of the Andes, the place known as "The Eyebrow of the Jun- gle".  Ragged, jutting canyon walls are half-hidden by the thick mists. The MAIN TITLE is followed by this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A narrow trail across the green face of the canyon.  A group of men make their way along it.  At the head of the party is an American, INDIANA JONES.  He wears a short leather jacket, a flapped holster, and a brimmed felt hat with a weird feather stuck in the band.  Behind him come two Spanish Peruvians, SATIPO and BARRANCA. Bringing up the rear are five Yagua INDIANS.  They act as porters and are wrangling the two heavily-packed llamas.  The Indians become increasingly nervous.  They speak to each other in bursts of Quechua.  The American, who is known to his friends as Indy, glances back at them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated) They're talking about the Curse again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and yells at the Indians in Quechua, his anger giving an indication of his own fears.  The party reaches a break in the canyon wall and takes the trail through it When they emerge, their destination is revealed to them in the distance.  Beyond a thick stand of trees is the vegetation-enshrouded TEMPLE OF THE CHACHAPOYAN WARRIORS, 2000 years old. The entire party is struck by the sight.  The Indians, terrified now, chatter away.  Suddenly the three at the back turn and run, dropping their packs as they go.  Bar ranca yells at the fleeing Indians and pulls his pistol out.  He starts to raise his arm to aim but Indy restrain it in a muscular grip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barranca looks evilly at Indy's hand upon him.  Indy re- leases him and smiles in a friendly way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't need them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Satipo watches this confrontation with some concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not carry supplies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll leave them.  Once we've got it, we'll be able to reach the plane by dusk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns back to the trail.  Satipo gets the two remainin Indians moving behind Indy.  Satipo and Barranca then hav a fast, silent communication:  Barranca indicates his de- sire to slit Indy's throat; Satipo gives him a look that says "Be patient, you idiot".

dialogues.speaker: THE APPROACH TO THE TEMPLE
dialogues.text: The party fans out to fight their way through the en- twined trees that guard the temple.  Visibility is cut to five feet in the heavy mist.  Satipo extracts a short, native dart from a tree and examines the point gingerly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (showing Indy) The Hovitos are near.  The poison is still fresh...three days.  They're following us, I tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they knew we were here, they would have killed us already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two Indiana jabber in Quechua, near hysteria.  Bar- ranca is sweating profusely, eyes darting.  He yells at the Indians in Quechua to "shut up". In the undergrowth, there is slithering movement. Indian #1 draws aside a branch and is faced with a hor- rific stone sculpture of a Chachapoyan demon.  The Indian is so frightened no sound comes out when he screams.  He turns and runs silently away. Indian #2 calls to his friend.  Getting no response, he steps in that direction.  A huge macaw, flushed from the undergrowth, screams and flies away.  Indian #2 does ex- actly the same thing, never to be seen again. Indy, Satipo and Barranca, just clearing the trees, look back in that direction.  They all turn to face the Temple It is dark and awesome.  Vegetation curls from every crevice, over each elaborate frieze.  The entrance-- round, open and black--has been designed to look like open jaws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this is where Forrestal cashed in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Competitor.  He was good, very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous) No one has ever come out of there alive. Why should we put our faith in you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy takes the weird feather from the band of his hat. From around its point, he slips a tightly rolled piece of parchment.  Barranca and Satipo exchange a quick "So that's where is was!" look.  They all kneel as Indy spreads out the parchment.  On it is one-half of a crude floorplan of the Temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one ever had what we have... partners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy fixes them with an expectant stare.  Satipo produces a similar, but folded, piece of parchment.  He lays it-- the other half of the floorplan--next to Indy's.  They all regard it for a moment, then Indy stands and walks toward the Temple.  Barranca's eyes are shining as they dart between the floorplan and Satipo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back turned) Assuming that pillar there marks the corner and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barranca is suddenly on his feet, quietly drawing his pis tol.  He raises it toward Indy as Satipo realizes with alarm what he's doing.  Too late.  Indy's head turns and he sees Barranca. Indy's next move is amazing, graceful and fast, yet totally unhurried.  His right hand slides up under the ba of his leather jacket and emerges grasping the handle of a neatly curled bullwhip.  With the same fluid move that brings Indy's body around to face the Peruvian, the whip uncoils to its full ten foot length and flashes out. The fall of the whip (the unplaited strip at the end of the lash) wraps itself around Barranca's hand and pistol. He could not drop the gun now if he tried. Indy gives the whip a short pull and Barranca's arm in jerked down, where it involuntarily discharges the gun into the dirt.  Barranca is amazed, but feels some slack in the whip and immediately raises the gun toward Indy again, cocking it with his free hand. Indy's face goes hard.  And sad. Indy sweeps his arm in a wide arc.  Barranca spins around enclosed in the whip, his gun hand stuck tight against his body.  Indy gives one more short jerk on the whip handle and Barranca's gun fires.  Barranca falls dead. Indy looks quickly at Satipo, who is shocked and fright- ened.  He raises his arms in supplication.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew nothing!  He was crazy! Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy looks him over, then nods.  He frees the whip from Barranca's body and picks up the man.  His eyes sweep the surrounding woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy and Satipo, carrying a torch, walk up the slightly inclined, tubular passage from the main entrance.  The interior is wet and dark, hanging with plant life and stalactites.  Their echoing footsteps intermittently overpower the sounds of loud dripping, whistling air drafts and scampering claws.

dialogues.speaker: HALL OF SHADOWS
dialogues.text: Indy leads the way down a twisting hallway, Satipo's torch barely lighting his way from behind.  Indy dis- appears in a shadow and when he reappears a moment later a huge black tarantula is crawling up the back of his jacket.  Indy doesn't notice and disappears into another shadow, emerging with two more tarantulas on his back. Satipo sees them and makes a frightened grunting sound. Indy looks at him, sees what he's pointing at and cas- ually brushes all three spiders off with his rolled whip, as he would a fly.  Satipo pirouettes for an in- spection and Indy flicks one off the Peruvian's back. Indy begins picking up little pocket-sized artifacts from the niches and ledges of the Temple.  He continues to do this as the men penetrate the Temple.  His collecting is quick and expert, evaluating the pieces in an instant, discarding some, stuffing others into his clothes, and never stopping his forward progress.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBER OF LIGHT
dialogues.text: The men reach an arch in the hall.  The small chamber ahead, which interrupts the hall, is brightly lit by a shaft of sunlight from high above.  Indy stops, looks it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?  Are you lost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy picks up a stick and throws it through the shaft of light.  Giant spikes spring together from the sides of the chamber with a ferocious CLANG!  And impaled on the spikes are the remains of a white man, half-fleshed, half skeleton, in explorer-type grab.  Indy reaches out and takes hold of the man's carcass.  As the spikes slowl retract, Indy pulls it free and seats the remains gently on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrestal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gulps) We can go no further.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Satipo, we don't want to be discouraged by every little thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy steps sideways into the chamber.  His back pressed against the very points of the retracted spikes, he moves along the edge of the light beam, and steps clear on the other side.  Satipo grimaces and begins sweating his way through.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRWAY
dialogues.text: Indy and Satipo come down stone stairs to a tight land- ing.  Framing the entry are a carefully strung network of dead vines, each somehow hooked into the wall, narrowing the opening even more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking torch) Let me see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lowers the torch to the floor of the landing.  The landing is carpeted with human skeletons, one on top of another, all squashed flat as cardboard.  Satipo gasps. Indy looks up at the ceiling of the landing, then steps onto skeletons, which make a cracking noise under his fee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try not to touch the vines.

dialogues.speaker: FOYER OF THE SANTUARY
dialogues.text: The men are in a high, straight hallway 50 feet long. The door at the end is flooded with sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senor, I think we are very close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy stands still looking at the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatient) Let us hurry.  There is nothing to fear here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what scares me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They begin walking down the hall side by side.  Satipo has inched a little ahead.  Suddenly his lead foot comes down and through the floor!  As Satipo begins to pitch forward, Indy grabs him by the belt and pulls him back. They both look down at the "floor". Indy swings his whip across the floor.  Fifteen feet of it cuts open beneath the lash, falling away to reveal black pit as wide as the hall.  The illusory floor was made of dust-covered cobwebs.  Satipo picks up a stone and drops it down the pit.  No sound.  The two men ex- change glances.  Indy looks up at the high roof of the hall.  He swings the whip up around a support beam, tests its strength with a pull and swings over the pit on the whip.  From the other side he swings the whip back to Satipo, who throws Indy the torch.  Satipo swings across. When they are both standing on solid floor there is a moment of quiet in which they hear, from far, far below-- SPLASH!  Indy wedges the whip handle into the wall and leaves it strung to the beam for quick retreat.

dialogues.speaker: THE SANTUARY
dialogues.text: A large, domed room.  Ten evenly-spaced skylights send their shafts of sunlight down to a unique tiled floor: white and black tiles laid out in a lovely, intricate pattern.  Indy and Satipo stand at the door and look across the wide room at the altar.  There, in the supreme hallowed spot, is a tiny jeweled figurine, Indy's real objective. Two torches, many years old, are in holders by the door. Indy takes one down and lights it.  He gives the regular torch to Satipo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's plenty of light, amigo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy kneels and uses the unlit end of the torch to reach out and tap a white tile.  It is solid.  He taps a black tile.  There is a whizzing sound and a tiny dark sticks in the torch.  Satipo points to the wall nearby: there is a recessed hole there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From that hole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy nods, stands and looks around the sanctuary.  The entire room is honey-comed with the same kind of hole. Satipo sees it too and is properly impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wait here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you insist, senor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Torch in hand, Indy begins his careful walk across the sanctuary.  Stepping only on the white tiles, he almost appears to be doing a martial arts kata.  Before each big move he waves the torch in front of him head to toe, looking at the flame.  Halfway out, he sees something on the floor and kneels to look at it. A dead bird lies on one of the white tiles.  Its body is riddled with little deadly darts.  This has great signi- ficance to Indy and he stands with even greater caution. He waves the torch ahead of him and at waist height an air current whips at the flame.  Indy ducks under it and leaves a burn mark on the white tile beneath it. Satipo watches, wide-eyed and mystified. Indy reaches the altar.  The tiny idol looks both fierce and beautiful.  It rests on a pedestal of polished stone. Indy looks the whole set-up over very carefully.  From his jacket he takes a small, canvas drawstring bad.  He begins filling it with dirt from around the case of the altar.  When he has created a weight that he thinks ap- proximates the weight of the idol, he bounces it a couple times in his palm concentrating.  It's clear he wants to replace the idol with the bag as smoothly as possible. His hand seems ready to do that once, when he stops, take a breath and loosens his shoulder muscles.  Now he sets himself again.  And makes the switch!  The idol is now in his hand, the bag on the pedestal.  For a long moment it sits there, then the polished stone beneath the bag drops five inches. This sets off an AURAL CHAIN REACTION of steadily increasing volume as some huge mysterious mechan rumbles into action deep in the temple. Indy spins and starts his kata back across the sanctuary at four times the speed. Satipo's eyes widen in terror.  He turns and runs.

dialogues.speaker: THE RETREAT
dialogues.text: The sanctuary has begun to rumble and shake in response to the mysterious mechanism.  Just as Indy goes out the door, a rock shakes loose from the wall and rolls onto th tiles floor.  Immediately, a noisy torrent of poison dart filles the room. IN THE FOYER, Satipo swings across the pit.  He makes it just as the whip comes undone from the beam, leaving Indy without an escape.  Satipo, extremely nervous, regards the whip a moment then turns back to face Indy, who has run up to the far side of the pit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No time to argue.  Throw me the idol, I throw you the whip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy hesitates, eyeing the rumbling walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no choice!  Hurry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy concurs with that assessment.  He tosses the idol across the pit to Satipo.  Satipo stuffs it in the front pocket of his jacket, gives Indy a look, then drops the whip on the floor and runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adios, amigo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy grimaces.  He had a feeling this might happen.  He looks around. AT THE VINED LANDING, Satipo flies through like a chubby ballet dancer and takes the steps five at a time. IN THE FOYER, Indy runs in full stride to the edge of the pit and broad jumps into space.  He doesn't make it.  His body hits the far side of the pit and he begins to slide out of view.  Only wild clawing with his fingers at the edge of the pit stops his descent.  With just the tips of his fingers over the edge, he begins pulling himself u AT THE CHAMBER OF LIGHT, Satipo has slowed down.  He begi to edge carefully around the light shaft. AT THE VINED LANDING, Indy sails through sideways and rol to a stop at the bottom of the steps.  His whip is graspe in his hand.  As he raises himself, he hears, from above the giant spikes of the Chamber of Light CLANG! and an abrupt, sickening rendition of SATIPO'S LAST SCREAM.  Ind runs up the steps.  The rumbling sound grows louder. AT THE CHAMBER OF LIGHT, Indy slides to a stop.  The spikes have retracted, taking Satipo's body to one side. Indy edges into the chamber with his back to the shaft of light.  Soon he is face to face with the dead Satipo; spikes protrude from several vital spots in the Peruvian' body.  Indy removes the idol from Satipo's pocket and moves quickly out the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adios.

dialogues.speaker: THE INCLINED PASSAGE
dialogues.text: Indy shoots out of a cut-off hallway and turns toward the exit.  The rumbling is very loud and now we see why: right behind Indy a huge boulder comes roaring around a corner of the passage, perfectly form-fitted to the passa way.  It obliterates everything before it, sending the st lactites shooting ahead like missles.  Indy dashes for the light of the exit.  His hat flies off his head.  Almo immediately it is crushed by the boulder.  Indy dives out the end of the passage as the boulder slams to a perfect fit at the entrance, sealing the Temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy lies on the ground, gasping for air.  A shadow falls across him and he looks up. WHAT HE SEES.  looming above him are three figures.  Two are HOVITOS WARRIORS in full battle paint and loin cloths They carry long blow guns.  But the man in the center dra Indy's attention.  He is a tall, impressive white man, dressed in full safari outfit including pith helmet.  His name is EMILE BELLOQ.  His face is thin, powerful; his ey hypnotic; his smile charming, yet lethal.  His heavily French-accented speech is deep, mellifluous, wonderful. Back beyond Belloq and his two escorts, thirty more Hovit Warriors hover at the edge of the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Jones, you choose the wrong friends.  This time it will cost you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belloq extends his hand.  Indy looks at it, then pro- duces the idol and hands it to Belloq.  Belloq extends his other hand, smiling.  Indy hands over his gun.  Bello sticks it in his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you thought I'd given up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyeing the Hovitos) Too bad they don't know you like I do, Belloq.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Yes, too bad.  You could warn them...if only you spoke Hovitos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that, Belloq turns dramatically and holds the idol high for all the Hovitos to see and says something in Hovitos.  There is a murmur of recognition and all the Indians, including Belloq's escorts, prostrate themselves upon the ground, heads down. Indy is immediately up and running toward the edge of the clearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Hovitos) Kill him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AT THE EDGE OF THE CLEARING, Indy disappears into the foliage.  An instant later, the leaves are peppered with a rain of poison darts and spears.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Indy runs like hell through steadily falling terrain. And always close behind, a swift gang of angry Hovitos. Occasionally they get close enough to send a dart or spear whizzing past Indy's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An amphibian plane sits in the water beneath a green clif Sitting on the wing is JOCK, the British pilot.  Indy breaks out of some distant brush and runs along the path at the top of the cliff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Get it going!  Get it going!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jock hops in and fires up the plane's engines.  Indy reaches a spot on the cliff above the place, glances back, them jumps into the river.  He comes up, swims to the plane and grabs a strut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jock starts the plane moving across the water as Indy walks across the wing and falls into the passenger com- partment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy relaxes and lies across the seat, a big smile on his face.  One hand drops to the floor of the cabin and Indy jumps, hitting his head.  On the floor of the cabin is a huge boa constrictor.  Indy tries to get his whole body onto the seat.  Jock sees what's happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mind his.  That's Reggie. Wouldn't hurt a soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stand snakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world's full of them, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on now, Sport, show a little of the old backbone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It soars off over the dark jungle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's authum and the pretty, New England campus out Indy's window reflects it in dazzling color.  A few weeks be- fore the start of classes.  Activity just picking up. Some students about. Indy is at a bookcase near the window and he looks quite different in this setting.  His outfit is tweedy, slightly rumpled in the professional style.  Part of his attention is focused in a book and he wears glasses to see the fine print.  The office is cramped, absolutely innundated with books, maps, etchings and archeological artifacts.  In fact, the only neat spot in the room right now is Indy's desk, which has been cleared off expressly for the benefit of-- MARCUS BRODY, the Curator of the National Museum in Wash- ington, D.C.  Brody is examining the small artifacts Indy pocketed on his way into the Peruvian Temple.  He occasio ally uses a jeweller's eyepiece to get a closer look.  Bu he is distracted, his concerns elsewhere, and it is this that his old friend Indy senses from across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think the idol will ever show up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Just because Belloq had it doesn't mean he kept it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy snaps the book closed and puts it on the shelf. He takes his glasses off and focuses on Brody.  At the windowed door to his office, two pretty Coeds pause for a moment, look in at their sexy Archeology professor, giggle and disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting it away from those Indians would be a neat trick (a hard look) I hope they got him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young male graduate student, Indy's TEACHING ASSISTANT, taps on the door and then pushes his way in with an arm- load of reference books.  Indy helps him find a spot for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't get the McNabe, Professor. Someone's got it checked out 'til next month when classes start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right, Phil.  Thanks a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eager to please) Will there be anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I'll see you Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Teaching Assistant leaves.  Brody is scowling as he examines the last of the artifacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, if you don't like them, I can always return them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they're beautiful.  The Museum will but them as usual.  No ques- tions asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought along some people today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Government.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned) Government?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, it's not about your business. (indicates the artifacts) They're from the Army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've already served.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Army Intelligence.  They're looking for Abner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy's course--a combination of archeology and anthro- pology--is taught in this amphitheater-type lecture hall. His desk and lectern hold large reference books; black- boards line the wall.  Bones, maps, charts festoon the walls. Indy leans against his desk talking with Brody and two uniformed Army officers, COLONEL MUSGROVE and MAJOR EATON, who are situated around the first seats in the classroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --But you did study under Professor Ravenwood at the University of Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) We haven't spoken in ten years. I'm afraid we had a bit of a fall- ing out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know nothing of his whereabouts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (negative) Just rumors.  Somewhere in Asia, last I heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Musgrove and Eaton exchange a look; they're disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Musgrove) Maybe Dr. Jones can make sense of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again the military men have a silent communication, de- ciding what to reveal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...you must understand, Dr. Jones, this is all strickly confidential.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday, one of our European sec- tions intercepted a Nazi communique from Cairo to Berlin.  We don't quite know what to make of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Musgrove takes a sheet from his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here it is--"Tanis development pro- ceeding.  Acquire headpiece, Staff of Ra, General Tengtu Hok, Shanghai. Locate Abner Ravenwood, U.S."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brody is excited.  He looks at Indy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tanis.  They must have discovered the lost ruins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy contemplates this big news; he's impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Tanis.  Ain't that somethin'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankly, we're a little suspicious... An American being mentioned so prom- inently in a secret Nazi cable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Ravenwood's no Nazi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what do they want him for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're looking for the headpiece to the Staff of Ra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicates his sheet) But it says here that's in China.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only half of it.  Ravenwood had the other half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would the Nazis want with this--this Staff of Ra?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can tell you that.  Over the last two years the Nazis have had teams of archeologists running around the world looking for all kinds of re- ligious artifacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.  Hitler's a nut on the subject.  Crazy.  He's obsessed with the occult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this Staff of Ra, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It all has to do with the Ark of the Covenant. (the Army guys look mystified) The chest the Hebrews used to carry around the Ten Commandments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it's the Army men who are impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Egyptian pharoah stole the Ark from Jerusalem and took it back to the city of Tanis.  A short time later, Tanis was consumed by the desert in a sandstorm that lasted a year.  But before that, the Phar- oah had had the Ark hidden away in a secret chamber called the Well of the Souls.  Which is where the Staff of Ra comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy moves to the blackboard and makes a quick sketch to give a rough idea of the system as he describes it. (And we get a glimpse of what an interesting and enthu- siastic teacher he must be)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now this was rather clever.  The Staff was really just a big stick-- oh, I don't know, say like this-- (he indicates about six feet) --no one really knows for sure.  Any- way, it was capped by an elaborate headpiece with a carving of the sun at the top.  What you had to do was take the Staff to a special map room in Tanis--it had the whole city laid out in miniature on the floor.  When you placed the Staff in a certain spot in this room, at a certain time of day, the sun would shine through a hole here in the headpiece and then send a beam of light down here--to the map--giving you the location of the Well of the Souls...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...where the Ark of the Covenant was kept.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Which is probably what the Nazis are after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this Ark look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look like?  Why, it's right here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy pulls a big format book from the stack on his lecter and flips through the pages until he finds a large color print.  The other men gather to look. THE PRINT fills the screen. It shows a Biblical battle.  The Israelite Army is van- quishing an opposition force.  At the forefront of the Israelite ranks, two men carry the Ark of the Covenant, a beautiful gold chest, crowned by two sculptured gold angels.  The men do not touch the Ark itself; rather they carry it by use of two long wooden poles which pass through rings in the corners of the Ark.  The painting is very dramatic, full of smoke, tumult and sinewy dying men.  But the most astounding thing in the picture is the brilliant jet of white light and flame issuing from the wings of the angels.  It pierces deep into the ranks of the retreating enemy, wreaking devastation and terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  That's what the Hebrews thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that supposed to be coming out of there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows...lightning...fire...the power of God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm beginning to understand Hitler's interest in this thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes.  The Bible tells of it level- ing mountains and wasting entire re- gions.  Moses promised that when the Ark was with you, "your enemies will be scattered and your foes fell be- fore you". (pause) An army which carries the Ark before it is invincible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eaton and Musgrove exchange worried looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, there's one other thing that Hitler undoubtably believes about the Ark... (a long pregnant pause) It's said that the Lost Ark will be recovered at the time of the coming of the True Messiah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Jones, you've been very helpful. I hope we can call on you again if we have questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most certainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brody and Indy exchange a look as they all shake and Brody starts to leave with the Army men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INdy's English Tudor, upper middle class hoem.  Quite toney; well beyond the financial reach of an honest college professor.  Marcus Brody has already rung the bell.  Indy opens the door.  He is dressed in a tuxedo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't really a good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy, it's important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lush tone continues here in Art Deco and shiny marble Indy motions Brody toward the study to one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be in in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Brody passes the entrance to the expansive living room he spots a beautiful, silk-gowned Harlow-type lounging on the sofa in front of a roaring fire.  She is sipping cham pagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brody enters the book-lined, dark-wooded study.  He paces for a moment before the fire which is dying in the fire- place, then spots something and goes over to Indy's big desk.  The surface is covered with open books, monographs maps and drawings--all about the Ark of the Covenant. Brody smiles; he knows his friend very well.  Indy comes in, closing the door behind him.  Brody turns to him with a triumphant expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want you to go for it.  And they'll pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Good work, Marcus.  I had a feeling this would happen.  And, of course, the Museum gets the Ark when we're done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy's manner is vigorous, agressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, here's the way it's gonna be. First, I'll high-tail it to Shanghai and get the piece from General Hok. Then I think I know where I can find Ravenwood.  If only I can get--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Hok's a tough customer.  They don't call him the Wild Boar for nothing. And he's tied in with the Japanese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll worry about that when the time comes.  My only hope is to find the Well of the Souls before the Nazis do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Pan Am Clipper flies west over the Pacific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy is barely into the front seat of a dilapidated Ford as the driver, BUZZ KEHOE, is peeling out into traffic.  In the back seat is a Chinese named BANG CHOW.  Kehoe zigs crazily through traffic with only his left hand as he reaches over to shake with Indy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzz Kehoe, Army Intelligence. You've met Bang Chow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the hurry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some German agents got here two hours ago.  Luckily, Bang was able to have them detained at Customs. We'll have to hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kehoe's car emerges from an alley.  Down the block is Tengtu Hok's modest, walled palace.  Kehoe's car slows a bit and Bang steps from the moving car with a small black suitcase in his hand.  While he heads down the street toward Hok's place, Kehoe's car continues across the street and into an alley on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Mercedes limousine appears round a corner and squeals to a stop at the front gate of the palace, which is manne by a sturdy Chinese Gateman.  There are three Germans in- side, one the driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kehoe, alone now, pushes a trash container casually into position to hide a newly created hole in the rear wall of Hok's Museum where several stone blocks have been removed He looks around and ambles back to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three Germans wait impatiently in a magnificent foyer A chime sounds and huge double doors open to reveal TENGT HOK, flanked by two uniformed Japanese Soldiers and a roved Chinese Advisor.  He wears a fantastic gold orna- mental robe.  Despite the majesty, however, nothing can disguise the fact that Hok is basically a wild, fat bar- barian; an animal.  Hok and his escort group bow in what is the beginning of a long welcoming ceremony.  The Germa exchange impatient glances but decide they should play it as it comes.  They bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No person in sight.  Instead, we see a magnificent dis- play of ancient artifacts.  Glass cases hold the velvet- couched pieces at random spots on the shining marble floor.  We hear an odd sound.  Near the floor on the rear wall of the museum, a steel ventilation grate moves.  A hand slides it gently across the marble.  Indy sticks his head out and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three Germans are being served tea and exotic deli- cacies.  A pleased Tengtu Hok watches from a throne-cushi When the tray of tiny delicacies is presented to him, he takes a massive handful, crushing them together on their way to his smiling mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge golden gong, seven feet in diameter, is suspended from the ceiling by a hook.  An enormous hammer hangs poised above it, from which emanate myraid tiny threads which run up and across the ceiling, then down to the various display cases.  Indy looks up at the gong, then continues his quick, quiet foray among the cases.  Be- yond him, a high window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hok and his visitors stand to go.  The German's pleased expressions make it clear they're finally on their way to the museum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy arrives at his destination.  The lovely, carved gold section of the headpiece is nested on purple velvet in a glass case.  At the bottom of the piece is a round hollow where the staff would fit.  There is a grunting sound be- hind Indy and he spins, already reaching for his revolver A fierce Japanese Samurai is running at Indy full speed down an aisle of display cases.  His sword is raised over his shoulder ready to cut Indy in half.  He's six feet a- way when Indy's gun levels and fires twice, blasting him backwards.  Indy is still looking over his gun when an- other samurai sword comes down from the side and knocks the pistol brutally out of Indy's grip; his hand avoids amputation by a quarter of an inch. An amazed Indy backs away from the crossing aisle as the Second Samurai steps in to face him, sword raised.  Indy backs away into an open space and his bullwhip appears in his hand.  He gives it one savage CRACK! to announce its arrival and the Samurai slows down, eyeing it curious The Samurai does not look unhappy about this confrontatio How pure it is--The Sword versus The Whip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tengtu Hok and the Germans have obviously heard something They are hurrying along the walkway at the side of the building, Hok in the lead.  Up ahead is the foot bridge which crosses from the palace to the museum entrance over a moat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lovely Mercedes limousine blows up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Germans spin toward the blast.  Drawing weapons, they run back to investigate.  Hok follows them, confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy and the Samurai face each other.  They're both breat ing hard from previous, no-contact passes at each other. Now Indy begins swinging the whip over his head again.  I whizzes out toward the Samurai's face.  The Samurai takes two lightning-quick cuts at the leather, but misses.  Ind swings for the Samurai's feet; the Japanese jumps nimbly, slashing at the whip.  Indy does it again.  The Samurai hops it.  Once more.  The Samurai is concentrating on hop ping it. Indy sees it.  The split second he wants.  The whip flash up from the floor and wraps solidly and irrevocably aroun the Samurai's neck.  Indy gives it a murderous pull and the Samurai is dead on his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hok and the three Germans are looking d-wn at the flaming remains of the Mercedes.  A look of concern crosses Hok's face.  He turns and runs back toward his beloved museum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy is at the case containing the headpiece.  He smashes the glass with a samurai sword, reaches in and grabs the piece.  Immediately, behind him, the huge hammer falls and the sound of the gong thunders through the museum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the sound of the gong, the running Hok skids to a halt with a crazed expression on his face.  He disappears for two seconds in an alcove and emerges holding a big, black Thompson Submachine Gun.  He runs across the foot bridge and is just barely over it when it blows up.  Hok, safe, looks behind him in amazement and then turns to the museu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The double doors at the entrance slam open to reveal Hok. Indy is halfway along an unprotected wall back to his ven tilation entry route.  Hok opens up on him, cutting off his retreat.  Indy jumps behind a marble column, which is promptly blasted with machine gun fire. Indy looks above him, sees the giant disk of the gong. Reaching up, pushing with tremendous effort, he maneuvers it off the hook.  It bounces down to the floor on its sid chipping the marble with its monstrous weight.  Indy stea ies it and then puts his whole body into rolling it acros the room toward the window.  As it starts to roll, Indy slips behind it and runs across the room with it. Hok can see the rolling gong.  He opens up on it. The vicious cacophony of machine gun fire is joined by the musical reports of bullets hitting the gong and ri- cocheting away.  Very, very noisy. Behind the gong, Indy gauges his move.  As the gong is about to be stopped by a marble bench, Indy talks a long stride onto the bench and dives through the glass of the high window.  Hok's bullets hit the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy lands in a shower of glass on the jutting roof of the museum's first floor.  He rolls to a crouch and is immediately being fired upon.  The Germans, cut off from the museum, are standing on the palace walkway firing at him.  Indy takes off fast for the rear of the museum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kehoe, craning to locate Indy, has the Ford rolling slowl along the back of the museum.  Bang scouts from the back seat.  Indy appears on the roof at a run, gauges the move ment of the car and jumps from the roof of the museum to the roof of the sedan.  Unfortunately, the roof of the old car can't take it and Indy's legs knife right on through to the interior, where he scares the hell out of Kehoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy squirms his way down into the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus!  Are you all right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he's felt better) Great.  Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kehoe guns it, throwing Indy back against the cushions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to get to Nepal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane flies west into the sunset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under a meager seat light, Indy is pouring over a jour- nal article by Abner Ravenwood and related map of Nepal. A few rows back, across the aisle, a trenchcoated Euro- pean Spy eyes Indy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge stuffed raven, wings spread wide, is mounted be- hind the long bar in the noisy, crowded saloon.  A lively mix of patrons is represented in the late hour tableau: Nepalese natives, fierce Sherpa mountain guides, sleazy international smugglers and fugitives, and, of course, mountain climbers from every corner of the earth.  A tall Nepalese, MAHDLO, is the bartender. In a corner near the fireplace trouble breaks out suddenly between the groups at two neighboring tables. Ferocious representatives from each table--one a wild- looking SHERPA, the other a muscular Australian CLIMBER-- jump up to face each other.  As the two contenders stand poised for action, their respective supporters shift in their places, fondling lethal ice axes and clubs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gmoiska!  Shurga rintoik!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye!  That'll be your last word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar has quieted ominously and so we hear with startli clarity when--a door behind the bar slams open with a hug BANG! and some Presence, too small to be seen as it moves through the forest of towering patrons, makes a beeline for the troubled corner of the bar.  A path clears for it The Sherpa and the Climber are about to kill each other when the Presence arrives directly between them:  she is MARION RAVENWOOD, twenty-five years old, beautiful, if a bit hard-looking.  At this moment, however, that look does not hurt.  She is not intimidated by the combatants; she jabs accusatory fingers into their chests.  She is angry as hell.  The patrons shrink under her gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That does it!  I've been patient with you no-goods long enough.  I'm not open at 2 o'clock for myself, you know.  It's all for you.  And how do you repay me:  Trouble and noise and blood on my floor!  I won't have it.  Everybody out! Out! Out!  We're closed.  Closed!  Do your killing outside!  And don't leave any bodies on the porch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place clears quickly.  Stragglers and grumblers are given special attention by Marion and Mahdlo, who has come from behind the bar carrying a big axe handle. Mahdlo herds the crows out the front door as Marion turns and walks behind the bar. A scowl on her lovely face, she has just begun clearing the bar of glasses when she notices one remaining Patron huddled over a glass at the far end of the bar.  Grimacin in exasperation, she heads that way like a locomotive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey you, deaf one!  I said out of my place.  I don't mean next Easter, I mean now--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is almost on him when Indy looks up smiling.  Marion stops, stares, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hits him with a solid right to the jaw, knocking him off the barstool on the floor.  He rubs his jaw and smiles up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to see you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up and get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) Take it easy.  I'm looking for your father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Well you're two years too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy's attitude changes instantly.  This is sad news.  He is silent for a long time.  Mahdlo comes in the front doo and hurries forward when he sees Indy with Marion.  He looks to her for guidance, but she stays him with a gestu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home, Mahdlo.  I'll see you to- morrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mahdlo is hesitant, but lays the axe handle on the bar an goes out.  Indy has been barely aware of him.  Now he set tles again on the barstool.  Marion has a vindictive look She'll let him stay, but she wants to inflict as much pai as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avalanche.  Up there.  He was dig- ging.  What else?  He spent his whole life digging.  Dragging me all over this rotten earth.  For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you find him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell no.  He's buried where he was working.  Probably preserved real good, too.  In the snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the hardness cracks.  She is on the verge of tears and does not want him to see them.  She turns away and takes a whiskey bottle from the shelf, then turns back to pout herself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a bad way to go.  Doing what he loved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vitriolic) Don't give me taht stuff!  What do you know? (she takes a drinks) I'm the one that was left in a bad way.  He didn't have a penny.  Guess how I lived, Mister Jones.  I worked here.  And I wasn't the bartender. (another swallow) Finally the guy that owned the joint went crazy.  Snow crazy.  They took his away screaming.  As they dragged him out, he said the place was all mine for life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks around the saloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you imagine a more evil curse? (pause) So far, it's working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not leave?  Go back to the States.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go back.  I'll get there.  Not that there's a soul there who knows my name of cares.  But I'll go.  And when I do, they'll know me.  'Cause I'm going to go back in style.  With money.  A soddamn lady!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you gonna get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I knew that, you think I'd still be running this dive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy looks at her, thinking.  Under his gaze, she blushes for reasons only she understands.  She looks into her glass and, for a moment, she softens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you something Indy.  I've learned to hate you in the last ten years.  But somehow, no matter how much I hated you, I always knew that someday you'd come through that door. I never doubted that.  Something made is inevitable. (hopefully) Why are you here...now...tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy takes a long time to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need one of the pieces your father collected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion's eyes go icy.  She swings at him again with her right, but this time he catches her at the wrist.  Then he stops her left, which she has brought up to slap him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You son-of-a-bitch!  You know what you did to me, to my life?  This is your handiwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never meant to hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a child!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You knew what you were doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess that depends on your definition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was wrong.  You knew it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy releases her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I did what I did.  I don't expect you to be happy about it. But maybe we can do each other some good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why start now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up and listen for a second.  I want that piece your father had. I've got money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This stops her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough to get you back to the States. Where are his things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone.  I sold it all.  It was all junk.  The junk he wasted his life on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving up) That's too bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy feels tired, defeated.  Marion is pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look disappointed.  I like that.  How's it feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy has to smile at her glee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods at his empty glass) What are you drinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seltzer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (refilling his glass) Real man's drink.  Me, I like scotch. And I like bourbon.  And vodka and gin.  I'm not much for brandy.  I'm off that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pours herself another as Indy watches, amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a tough broad now, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no act, pal.  This ain't Sche- nectady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can only say I'm sorry so many times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion looks at him thoughtfully, takes a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really have money?  You don't look rich. (Indy nods) I may be able to locate some of his things.  I know who's got them. What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bronze piece, about this size.  In the shape of the sun.  Probably broken off at the bottom.  Has a little hole in it, off-center. Does that sound familiar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion thinks, nods slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know where it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.  How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three thousand.  American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (negative) That'll get me back, but not in style.  This doodad must be pretty importnat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge smile lights up Marion's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it would happen eventually. I knew it.  Something had to go my way. (pours herself another drink) I've got to think this out.  I'm used to bargaining with yaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, five thousand.  That's all I can give you now.  I can get you more when you land in the States.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You word, huh? (Indy nods) Just like you said you'd be back last time?  That was your word too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm back, aren't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion sneers and they smile together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come back tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I said so, that's why.  It's about time I called the shots in this relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy nods, gets up to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute.  Leave the five thou- sand here. (Indy hesitates) You want trust, give some.  I want to smell your money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy thinks about this a moment, then reaches inside his shirt and pulls cash from a money belt.  He lays five gra on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy starts fro the door. Marion takes another think. She is getting high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it.  Come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving back) Bossy, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.  Give me a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy looks into her eyes, then leans over the bar and kisses her deeply.  When the kiss ends, their faces are very close.  Marion is flushed.  She liked it and would like more.  She raises her glass between them to disci- pline herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of my place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy smiles and walks to the front door.  Then, without looking back--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gone.  Marion stares after him, thinking.  She takes a drink.  Then slowly, her hand comes up to loose the scarf that is draped around her throat.  It falls away, revealing her graceful neck above the dipping top of her blouse.  Hanging there on a gold chain against her white skin is a sun-shaped golden medallion.  The bottom looks broken off.  Marion lifts the medallion so she can see it in her hand, then looks thoughtfully after Indy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy sits thinking at the wheel of an old car.  Finally, he puts the car in gear and drives away. Across the street, the shadow in a doorway comes to life. A dark form steps out to look at Indy's departing car; it is the European Spy from the DC-3.  He hurries off in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion stands before the fire that is shrinking in the fireplace.  She jabs at it abstractedly with a poker, thinking.  Suddenly tears well up in her eyes.  She lets the poker slip from her hand, wipes away the tears.  She walks across the room to the end of the bar, still clut- tered with bottles and glasses, and stops at the pile of American money Indy has left.  She takes the chain from around her neck and lets the medallion slide off it into her hand.  She places it on the bar next to the pile of money, thinking.  Then, having reached some decision, she picks up the pile of bills, walks up the back of the bar and pulls a small wooden box from under the bar.  She fli open the top, puts the cash inside and closes the top. She leaves the box on the bar and starts back toward the medallion.  The front door of the saloon bursts open and Four Bad Men come in.  Marion, halfway between the valuable possessions and not wishing to draw attention to either, stops where she is. The Four Bad Men who advance on her are: 1.) the obvious leader, a short, vile, sadistic German in spectacles by the name of BELZIG. 2.) a trenchcoated SECOND NAZI. 3.) a ratty-looking NEPALESE and 4.) a mean MONGOLIAN.  The second NAZI and the MONGOLIAN both carry submachine guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Fraulein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar's closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are not thirsty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mongolian and the Nepalese poke around, checking to make sure there's no one else there. Down at the end of the bar, the medallion lies partially hidden by surrounding glasses and bottles.  The Second Nazi stops very near it, but turns his back to it to face Belzig and Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name thing your friend Dr. Jones wanted.  Surely he told you there would be other interested parties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, the man is nefarious.  I hope for your sake he has not yet acquired it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, are you willing to offer more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost certainly.  Do you still have it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  But I know where it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belzig's smile fades at this news.  He's not a patient so Marion is chilled by the look.  She turns and moves to th shelf of bottles behind her, reaching high for one, very near the large stuffed raven.  He hand lingers there a moment and we see-- From an angle behind the stuffed raven, that the left win spread hides a Baretta automatic pistol.  Marion's hand i very near it, but withdraws with only a whiskey bottle as the Mongolian walks toward her behind the bar. Marion opens the bottle before Belzig, who watches her intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout a drink for you and your men?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Second Nazi lights up at this suggestion.  Belzig giv him a withering look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will stick to the business at hand, Fraulein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tough) Fine.  Why don't you come back to- morrow when Jones is here and we'll have an auction?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belzig gives her a cold look then turns and walks over to ward the firplace.  As soon as his back is turned, the Second Nazi grabs the nearest whiskey bottle and takes a quick pull.  In so doing, he leaves the medallion complet exposed.  Marion is aware of this as she looks at him.  B he quickly puts the bottle down again, obscuring the meda lion, when Belzig speaks from the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid an auction is not possible. (pause) Your fire is dying here, Fraulein. (a beat, then threatening) Why don't you tell us where the piece is right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Herr Mac, I don't know who you're used to dealing with, but no one tells me what to do in my place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belzig, still looking in the fire, sneers and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Americans!  You're all alike.  Frau- lein Ravenwood.  I'll show you want I'm used to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He motions with his hand.  The Mongolian moves up behind Marion and lifts her roughly over the top of the bar, knocking over bottles and spilling liquor.  He deposits her on the other side, where the Nepalese and the Second Nazi flank her and hold her cruelly, arms behind her back Marion raises a ruckus. Belzig turns from the fireplace.  In his hand is the poke its end glowing orange.  He advances on Marion.  Marion stops yelling, her eyes widen in terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!  I can be reasonable--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That time is passed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The glowing poker point moves inexorably across the room toward Marion's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need that.  I'll tell you everything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know you will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belzig has no intention of stopping now.  The glowing tip is approaching Marion's face.  The Nepalese watches with savage glee. The tip of the poker is five inches from Marion's nose when there is a loud CRACK! and the fall of Indy's bull- whip wraps around the middle of the poker and tears it out of Belzig's hands.  The poker sails high across the room, free of the whip, and lands in the heavy curtains that cover one window.  The curtains immediately burst into flame. The four Bad Men look in surprise toward the front en- trance.  Indy is poised there, the whip in his right hand, a .45 automatic raised toward them in his left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now everything begins to happen very fast-- The Mongolian had just come around the bar at the end opposite the medallion.  He dives back to crouch behind the end of the bar, raising his submachine gun. Belzig and the Second German dive behind tables near the bar.  The Nepalese is slower to leave Marion, he draws a Luger.  Indy's .45 barks and the Nepalese dies spinning against the bar.  Indy fires in the direction of the Mongolian. Marion swings up over the top of her bar.  Belzig fires a her, but his bullets smash bottles behind the bar and thu into the raven. Marion flattens out on the floor behind the bar as bullet hit above her.  She reaches up, snatches the axe handle from where Mahdlo left it, and begins crawling down the length of the bar toward-- The Mongolian, who sticks his submachine gun out and fire blindly in Indy's direction. Indy is in a crouch behind a table, trying to get a shot at someone.  He doesn't notice in the din and confusion when the door bursts open.  An incredible, fearsome GIANT SHERPA, almost seven feet tall, soars in and tackles Indy from behind.  The whip flies from Indy's hand as he and the Giant Sherpa roll across the floor, upsetting furnitu The Mongolian, seeing this, stands up confidently.  Mario rises behind him and bashes him over the head with the ax handle.  He goes down and out. Fire has completely engulfed the curtains and is working across the ceiling on decorative yak skin bunting.  A bur ing fragment drops to the top of the bar, which immediate lights up, fueled by the spilled alcohol.  Full whiskey bottles explode like Molotov cocktails. Rolling on the floor, Indy and the Giant Sherpa are fight ing for control of Indy's .45.  Belzig sees this and shou to the Second Nazi, who is rising from cover with submach gun in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot them both!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's our man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do as I say!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both the Giant Sherpa and Indy hear this.  The Giant Sherpa exchanges an alarmed look with Indy and together they swing the .45 around toward the surprised Second Nazi.  Two blasts blow him away. That done, Indy brings a brass spittoon down on the Giant Sherpa's wrist and the .45 slides away.  Indy jumps up an kicks the Giant Sherpa, who barely seems to feel it.  He grabs Indy and flips him effortlessly onto a table. Belzig now has a clear shot at Indy.  He raises his luger Marion, at the end of the bar, finally gets the hand of the Mongolian's submachine gun.  It roars to life in the general direction of the ceiling. Belzig runs for cover as Marion gets control of the gun and levels it.  Belzig dives around the end of the bar opposite Marion.  When he has set himself, he peeks up ov the edge of the scorched bar.  The alcohol fire has moved down the bar and now, much to Belzig's surprise, he finds himself staring at the fire-blackened sun-shaped medallio His eyes widen.  He cannot believe his good fortune.  Wit out hesitation he picks up the metal medallion, palming i Immediately there is a sickening searing sound and Belzig expression changes from joy to agony.  He screams in pain and tries to shake the red-hot medallion from his skin. Marion opens up and the bar starts to splinter in front o Belzig.  The medallion comes free of Belzig's hand and rolls across the floor. Belzig has had enough.  In excruciating pain, he turns, sees a window, runs and dives through the glass. An exhausted Indy uses his whole body to upend the Giant Sherpa, who lands hard on his back.  They are surrounded by flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belzig has his burned hand stuck deep in the snow.  Now he withdraws it, steaming, and scurries off into the nigh like a wounded animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion throws down the empty submachine gun and moves through the flames to the center of the bar where she lef the box with the five grand.  She finds the remains of th box and its contents:  a shapeless pile of ash and charre wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unbelievable!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of the bar, the Mongolian has come back to lif He shakes out his head, then reaches inside his coat and pulls out a Mauser pistol. Indy smashes a chair over the head of the Giant Sherpa an the huge creature goes down. The Mongolian points his Mauser through the smoke and fla at Indy.  Suddenly, the Mongolian is shot dead. Marion stands beneath her stuffed raven with the Baretta. Indy moves quickly through the flames, his eyes scanning the floor.  He picks up his bullwhip and his crumpled fel hat.  He peers through the smoke till he spots Marion mov ing among the burning furniture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not without that piece you want!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion nods, kicks aside a burning chair.  Another burnin beam falls from the roof.  Indy pulls Marion close to him protectively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it!  I want you out of here. Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins dragging her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) There!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She breaks away from him, darts back and picks the hot medallion up in the loose cloth of her blouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around) You burned down my place!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (figuratively) I owe you plenty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (literally) You owe me plenty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) You're something!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am something.  And I'll tell you exactly what--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds up the medallion possessively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your partner!

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: First we see the sprawl, the soaring minarets, the an- cient skyline.  Then we're closer, in the narrow, exotic streets, teeming with life:  fierce-looking men in tatter galabiyas, black-gowned women with veiled faces, ragged, barefoot children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy and Marion have been welcomed like family into the crowded home of SALLAH, his wife FAYAH, and their NINE CHILDREN (ages 4 - 18).  Fayah, a huge, imposing woman, appears, at first glance, to be the power in the house. Sallah, a small, cheerful, energetic fellow in his for- ties defers to his wife in all matters of little importan Suddenly the general liveliness at the children's table escalates into pandemonium, attracting the attention of the adults.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence! (there is silence) Why do you forget yourselves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gaggle of grinning off-spring parts to reveal in thei midst--a MONKEY.  It is munching some flat Arab bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?  Who brought this animal in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the children chatter their innocence at once.  The Monkey chatters too; it's an entertainer.  The Monkey jumps from the children's table to the adults' and struts slowly up toward Marion, who thinks it's the cutest thing she ever saw.  When it reaches her, it takes off its tur- ban and does a deep, grand bow to her.  She is deligthed and takes the Monkey into her arms.  The Monkey kisses her cheek.  The children laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, thank you.  I like you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it shall be welcome in our house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no!  You don't have to have it around if you don't want it--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) All of Allah's creatures are welcome here.  You please us by letting us please you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy and Sallah sit in the small, protected courtyard. Sallah holds the two sections of the headpiece, the medal lion and the base, and has for the first time fitted them together.  They fit perfectly and complete the headpiece. He peruses the markings on the headpiece quizzically.  In is cleaning and loading a .45 automatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew the Germans would hire you, Sallah.  They couldn't have an ex- cavation in the desert without the best digger in Egypt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All Arabs look alike to them, Indy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about the map room at Tanis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We found it three days ago.  I broke through myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those Nazis are moving awfully fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Frenchman is helping them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belloq.  So he got away from the Indians.  This is going to be more interesting that I thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid this has put the Germans close to finding the Well of the Souls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicates the headpiece) Even Belloq won't be able to find it without that.  Can you make anything of those markings?  They're nothing I'm familiar with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head "no") But I know someone who might.  You can go to see him tomorrow. (a worried expression) Indy...something bothers me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, my friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sallah finds it hard to say.  When he finally speaks, his words are accompanied by a strange, eerie, foreboding rus of wind through the courtyard.  Just a coincidence we mig suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the Ark.  If it is there, at Tanis...It is not something man was meant to disturb...Death has always surrounded it.  It is not of this earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind dies down.  Indy shakes off a chill and stares thoughtfully at his friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy and Marion are briskly walking along one of Cairo's busy bazaar streets. Vendors with fine cloth, pottery, baskets, jewelry, etc line the street.  Marion has the Monkey from Sallah's house on her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really need that monkey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm surprised at you, Indy. Talk- ing that way about our baby.  He's got your looks, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your brains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Indy and Marion turn a corner, the Monkey seems to notice something and immediately jumps from Marion's shoulder and hurries off at a frantic pace down the stree

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking disappointed) Hey!  Hey!... where're you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dragging Marion on) He'll be OK.  Come on.  Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Monkey is seen running around another corner and jumps into the waiting arms of MONKEY MAN, who appears to be like a beggar with a dirty turban and an eye patch. MONKEY MAN immediately hurries down the street and passes into a building. In the building are two GERMAN AGENTS. MONKEY MAN and the MONKEY both give the Heil Hitler salut and engage in quick talk. MONKEY MAN quickly leaves the two GERMAN AGENTS and gets back to the street. He is obviously shadowing Indy and Marion. Indy and Marion are just now passing by the MONKE MAN ducks back behind some baskets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy and Marion are passing under a balcony where a lone GERMAN AGENT stands watch. After they pass, the AGENT nod to some BAD ARABS who are hiding in the shadows of the street.  In a moment, Indy and Marion pass by the break. Monkey Man turns and looks up at a roof further down the alley.  He waves with his hand.  Someone up there waves back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy and Marion have reached a tiny square, made even more cramped by its use as a small bazaar.  They have started working their way through the crowd when several Bad Arabs and a German Agent begin to converge on them. Indy immediately sees what's happening and pulls the bull whip from his jacket.  The first Bad Arab to reach them gets hit in the mouth by the handle of the whip.  Now all hell breaks loose, with Bad Arabs, Innocent Shoppers, bas kets of fruit and tables of goods flying every which way in the constricted space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Marion) Run!  Get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy catches a dagger-wielding Bad Arab around the legs with the whip and flips him.  Marion is reluctant to leav Indy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, dammit!  Go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion goes.  She runs off between two buildings.  A Bad Arab takes off after her.  Monkey Man, now standing at the edge of the square, points at Marion.  The Monkey jumps off his shoulder and follows Marion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marion runs along the narrow space and soon encounters a five foot wall. She flops over it.  The Bad Arab is right on her heels.  He reaches the wall and vaults over. On the other side of the wall, the Bad Arab lands in a crouch, looks ahead and doesn't see Marion.  Immediately a heavy earthen pot smashes over his head, putting him out.  Marion steps from an alcove and starts to run to- ward the street at the other end of the walkway.  Suddenl another Bad Arab and a new German Agent appear in the street at that end.  Before they can spot her, Marion retreats to the alcove again.  There is a huge rattan basket sitting there.  Marion climbs in and closes the top above her. The only witness:  The Monkey, who is now perched on the fire foot wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaos.  An entire booth of pots and pans collapses on a Bad Arab and a German Agent as Indy whips away a support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chattering Monket leads a German Agent and two Bad Arabs to Marion's hiding place, gesturing manically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy ducks under the swinging blade of a huge Arabian sword and kicks the Bad Arab Swordsman in the groin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The German Agent leads the way as the two Bad Arabs carry the huge basket above their heads.  The basket top has been fastened closed, but Marion is making a fuss inside. At the place where the street cuts across the far side of the bazaar, Marion is able to wedge the top open one inch and screams--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy-y-y-y!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indy has heard her.  He looks across the square as the basket and its escorts disappear beyond a building.  One last Bad Arab rises before him.  Indy's whip flashes and the Bad Arab's robe falls down to his ankles.  Indy fran- tically pushes his way through the panicked mass of human ity in the direction the basket has gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bad Guys move the basket as fast as they can through streets, alleys and passageways thick with people.  Indy always seems to round a corner just in time to catch a glimpse of the basket before it disappears around a new corner.  Indy must fight a flow of humanity as powerful as an ocean riptide.  Finally, at the head of one par- ticularly crowded alley, Indy leaps up onto a wall for a clearer view.
